talks.speaker: Magdalena Stenius

talks.speaker: Joonatan Kauppi

talks.title: CI Pipelines with Azure
talks.speaker: Matti Järvinen

talks.speaker: Dusan Turajlic

talks.speaker: Ilmari Koskinen

talks.speaker: Farzad Yousefzadeh

talks.speaker: Klaus Jokinen

talks.speaker: Tân Bùi

talks.speaker: Dusan Turajlic

talks.speaker: Konsta Purtsi

talks.title: Refactoring Patterns
talks.speaker: Dusan Turajlic

talks.title: Observability Driven Development
talks.speaker: Andy Davies

talks.title: Accessibility Quick Wins You Can Implement Today
talks.speaker: Daniel Yuschick

talks.title: Should you use GraphQL?
talks.speaker: Viktor Lukashov

talks.title: Reviewing code - live
talks.speaker: Petro Silenius

talks.title: The Art of Work Estimation
talks.speaker: Teemu Suoranta

talks.title: European Cookie Legislation and You
talks.speaker: Jere Laine

talks.title: Adapting to sensible constraints: Building a startup with Remix & Supabase
talks.speaker: Niko Korvenlaita

talks.title: Let's write a Language Server!
talks.speaker: Matias Huhta

talks.title: Everything would be just fine if only there were no other people
talks.speaker: Elisa Heikura

talks.title: Make the most of your UI testing
talks.speaker: Ossi Hanhinen

talks.title: How to (not) to handle security issues - we are all in this together
talks.speaker: Joona Hoikkala

talks.title: The Road to Intl.MessageFormat
talks.speaker: Eemeli Aro

talks.title: Flutter Stuff
talks.speaker: Jukka Palomäki

talks.title: Better accessibility with a user-centric view
talks.speaker: Marianna Österlund
talks.description: Web accessibility is much more than regulations and restrictions. It is based on real people with real problems and needs. By understanding all the users everything makes a lot more sense. In her talk Marianna addresses the ‘why’ of accessibility – and a little bit of the ‘how’, too.

talks.title: Visual programming and executable models
talks.speaker: Farzad Yousefzadeh
talks.description: Let's look at the traditional way of making software, the importance of diagramming and ideas to take diagrams to the next level where they can be used as the single source of truth for the software behavior generating rest of the software such as tests, documentation and the runtime.

talks.title: Refactoring my hobby project with Next.js
talks.speaker: Jurkka Lemmetti
talks.description: My journey of updating old Ember project to use Next.js v13 framework.

talks.title: Quick introduction to Qwik
talks.speaker: Juho Vepsäläinen
talks.description: Qwik is a contender entering the crowded space of JavaScript frameworks. In this brief talk, you will learn why you should take it seriously and how Qwik is shaking the foundations of web development as we know it.

talks.title: Take a mess. Make a mess. Refactor to shape
talks.speaker: Aki Salmi
talks.description: Ever seen a code that needs modifications, lack tests and you fear touching would break the working software somewhere else? In this talk, we learn a way to take a mess - a working code that does provide value every single day - turn that code into testable, cover it with tests and then to use a counter-intuitive way to refactor that code into something where domain concepts find their own places while making modifications easy. Taking an untested mess is a challenge we face in real life. This talk is based on a series of exercises that can be worked on separately, built into a bigger code challenge. The talk goes through the thinking on how to approach such a challenge. Why is it important to add test cases? Why is it important to make the production code testable, in order to be able to test it? Why test readability is so important? And then - how to make a mess to let the design to find it’s shape. This talk has 3 concepts 1) How to turn hard-to-test code into easy-to-test code 2) How to write a test case (and why) 3) How to find a business abstraction thinking outside-in

talks.title: Towards buildless environments through Import Maps
talks.speaker: Matias Huhta
talks.description: Now that import maps are supported by all major browser vendors, utilizing ES Modules has become a lot better. ES Modules are a modern way of re-using Javascript code in web applications through modular organization of code. Import maps allow us to resolve module specifiers in static and dynamic imports, providing us control over module resolution in our modern web applications. We'll be taking a hands on look at what we can achieve with import maps and how they can provide a buildless, bundleless development and deployment experience.

talks.title: Keys To An Accessibility Mindset
talks.speaker: Daniel Yuschick
talks.description: Accessible design is good design. In this talk, we will discover the importance of web accessibility, and highlight how we all benefit from the accessible design choices all around us. Gain an understanding of the four principles of web accessibility, before exploring three keys for applying those principles naturally to your design and development process. This presentation will include experiences of advocating for and leading company initiatives toward accessibility, as well as practical examples demonstrating the before and after of our keys to an accessibility mindset.

talks.title: Frontend Pub Quiz
talks.speaker: Teemu Mäntyharju
talks.description: Let's have some fun together. How well do you know frontend development and how much have you paid attention during the past 49 events?

talks.title: Use Testing Library for all of your frontend tests
talks.speaker: Ari-Pekka Koponen
talks.description: Most frontend developer's struggle with writing great frontend tests and finding tools that make writing tests enjoyable. In this talk we see why the Testing Library has become many frontend developers' favorite library for testing UIs and learn how it helps you improve the accessibility of your applications while you write your normal UI tests.

talks.title: It's all about images, part 1
talks.speaker: Jere Laine
talks.description: Welcome to the joyful yet mysterious world of image processing! Images can make or break a website. Join us to learn all the tips, tricks and black magic needed to make your images as presentable and accessible as possible.

talks.title: Writing Javascript, but with types!
talks.speaker: Matias Huhta
talks.description: Every once in a while, you stumble upon a codebase that is written in plain old JavaScript, and you remember how unsafe it feels to write code without a type system supporting you. With modern tooling and some JSDoc you can turn a JavaScript project into a type safe one, without compromising on portability or developer experience. And as you delve deeper into the rabbit hole, maybe even unlock some new features. Developers of large projects like Svelte and Remix have already started transitioning to a more frictionless developer experience by embracing Javascript as it is, but by providing valuable typeing support through JSDoc and the TypeScript compiler. In this hands-on talk we'll take a look at the featureset a JSDoc + Javascript development environment provides, and how you can write type safe code without the drawbacks of build systems and transpiling.

talks.title: Launch confidently with k6 performance testing
talks.speaker: Mattias Nixell
talks.description: A brief introduction to k6 performance testing and its simplicity. A couple of "gotchas" and how to work around them. Finally, a practical code example from one of Vincit's projects.

talks.title: Data fetching & mutations in Next.js 14
talks.speaker: Tuomo Kankaanpää
talks.description: Data fetching is a core part of any application. Since the introduction of the app router, we now have multiple ways we can fetch and mutate data in our Next.js application. In this talk we will take a look on different ways to handle data fetching & mutations in Next.js 14 application.

talks.title: Focusing on focus; styling focus indicators in 2023
talks.speaker: Fotis Papadogeorgopoulos
talks.description: In this talk, we’ll step through the landscape for styling focus indicators in 2023. We will look at :focus-visible edge cases, styling to follow borders, support for dark and high contrast modes, and finally explore browser standards and a good bit of team communication. Join for some fun examples and bring your questions or focus styling pains 😁

talks.title: Mastering the "Good Enough" Technical-Business Equation in Frontend Development: Sketching with Wireframes
talks.speaker: Joonas Heinonen
talks.description: I'll be talking about the delicate balance between technical excellence and aligning with your organization's business objectives using visualization as the key enabler. Frontend development isn't just about writing code; it's about creating user experiences that drive your business forward. How can you ensure that your frontend work directly contributes to achieving business objectives? We'll explore the role of wireframes as a baseline tool bridging the communication gap between technical teams and business stakeholders. We'll emphasize the importance of collaborative workflows, where business stakeholders, designers, developers, and customers work closely together to refine wireframes and prototypes. At the end of the talk you should be having some thoughts about how you can accelerate the validation of business goals with "good-enough" frontend first -approach.

talks.title: Lightning talks
talks.speaker: Multiple speakers
talks.description: A session of 5-minute talks

special.name: Student Night with Asteriski and If
special.description: We organized a special student night with students from Asteriski with talks from Juhis and Roosa. Event was sponsored and hosted by If.

talks.title: Guide to Effective Test Automation (tools and strategies)
talks.speaker: Aki Salmi
talks.description: In the realm of modern software development, mastering the art of effective automated testing is essential. This talk is designed to empower participants with comprehensive insights and actionable strategies to enhance the stability, speed, and independence of unit tests and introducing a pattern that helps to write system level tests, especially within the context of event-driven microservices.

talks.title: Detect commonly undetected accessibility issues
talks.speaker: Eyal Eshet
talks.description: We’ll go through some of the common accessibility issues that automated tools cannot detect, learn how to detect them and hopefully avoid them in the first place. Special guest: the Swedish Chef :)

special.name: Code in the Dark
special.description: 4 teams, 4 challenges, 15 minutes per round. We organized a Code in the Dark event.

talks.title: From Frontend Development to Native Mobile - Two Experiences
talks.speaker: Eeva-Jonna Panula & Marianne Sirén
talks.description: Eevis and Marianne are both frontend developers who switched to Android development. In this talk, they share their experience, what they’ve learned in the process, and what has been surprising. So come hear their stories and the answer to the question: Are they ever going back to web development?

talks.title: Building Better Components: A Journey to a More Resilient Frontend
talks.speaker: Daniel Yuschick
talks.description: Components are at the core of modern development. However, for as much as they can help empower our work, they can harm and hinder it. Building resilient components requires careful planning and collaboration. And, of course, requires avoiding the common pitfalls of component design.This talk will teach us how to avoid common mistakes in component design. We’ll learn how to build resilient frontends that can build trust across teams and grow with our products.

talks.title: Building a one-size-fits-all design system with web components
talks.speaker: Matti Haapamäki
talks.description: In my first ever talk we'll dive into how and why my team is building a web components based design system. We'll discuss the challenges of working with multiple frontend technologies, diverging needs of stakeholders, and how the design system helps us gain credibility and autonomy to focus on more meaningful problem solving. My goals for the talk are to serve as the first touch point to design systems for frontend engineers and to give helpful pointers on how to (and whether you should) get started.

talks.title: Hands-on Hilla - Practical introduction to the Hilla Framework
talks.speaker: Sami Ekblad
talks.description: We demonstrate Hilla's blend of Java’s backend strength with TypeScript’s frontend benefits for frontend developers. Through a real example of vaadin.com/directory, we look into how to build a web application and Hilla’s architecture and its backend-to-frontend integration into a full-stack application.

talks.title: Making Your Own Toy Languages - Why and How?
talks.speaker: Juho Friman
talks.description: I will be give a brief introduction on how to get started on making your own programming language from scratch, and I hope you find the inspiration to make your own little language. It won't become new Python or Typescript, but I promise that you will learn more about programming and programming languages than ever before if you just take a walk to the wild side. This talk will not give you a complete recipe, but gives you insight on programming language internals on really shallow level. We will not go there where the dragons are. That is your job. Have you ever wondered why in most programming languages variable names can't start with digit but can contain digits? Let's find out and many more interesting things about language internals in digestable manner.

talks.title: Stretching the concept of UI/frontend with PALL0
talks.speaker: Henrik Terävä
talks.description: I'll take you through the fascinating world of PALL0, where frontend design goes beyond the screen into tangible interactions. Imagine a UI where a squeeze replaces a button press, a simple rotation becomes your selection tool and actions can be determined by the physical distance between devices. I'll explore how these dimensions transform the user interface and challenge us to think outside the conventional pixel box. We'll delve into creating interfaces where actions are triggered by physical movement, such as throwing an object to a precise height with certain speed of rotation. I'll discuss how we navigate design when our 'screen' is a mere 64x64 pixels, how statistics are replaced with emotions, and how the PALL0 platform’s sensors redefine user engagement, making every interaction both intuitive and playful. Join me in reimagining the potential of UI as we know it.

talks.title: Navigating Right-to-Left: Insights into Localising Websites for RTL Languages
talks.speaker: Aapo Komppa
talks.description: Introduction to issues we had solved and things we noticed when doing a website localised for language read right-to-left. I’ll go through this with the eyes of a software developer but will dip little in UI/UX design. I’ll explore how popular libraries, frameworks and web-development tools handle RTL layout. I will also show how to localise both LTR and RTL languages. I don’t speak any language which uses RTL script so this will be explained based on experience I got while making an Arabic website for a client.

talks.title: The Annual Turku ❤️ Frontend Pub Quiz
talks.speaker: Teemu Mäntyharju
talks.description: Returning after a glorious debut last year, Teemu has put his quiz master hat on and brewed together a new pub quiz to finish the spring with. This time, with rewards!

talks.title: New Era of Sliders via CSS Overflow
talks.speaker: Teemu Suoranta
talks.description: Sliders are widely used in the web and most prominently in mobile where the screen real-estate is the most limited. The usage of sliders have transformed from auto-playing full-wide hero carousels to more subtle UIs. Mobile performance, touch gestures and accessibility requirements have put more requirements on the libraries we use. I'll demonstrate how we can use CSS overflow:auto and JS enhancements to power-up the new generation of sliders that some notable sites like IKEA is already using. I show the possibilities and limitations of CSS and what kind of native JS APIs browser offers for this kind of slider. I have created a library @evermade/overflow-slider that is powered by these techniques.

talks.title: Tailwind all the things!
talks.speaker: Aarni Koskela
talks.description: ... or the steps and tooling to transform an application from Bootstrap to a bespoke Tailwind-based design system without too many hiccups. Warning: talk may contain live demo.

talks.title: Browser bugs, feature detection and you: tips for making forward-looking frontends
talks.speaker: Fotis Papadogeorgopoulos
talks.description: One of the wonderful parts about the web, is that it is constantly evolving. This evolution solves common pain points, leads to less code sent to clients, and supports more performant and ambitious applications. However, this evolution brings pressure on web developers to track changes, and adapt our code to new practices. Browsers adopt features at different rates, so code paths often have to fork based on capabilities. In this talk, we will step through common ways of keeping a code base healthy in this changing environment, such as feature detection, automatic code transpilation and manual User Agent sniffing. We will also look at a way of handling an often-overlooked inverse case; knowing when to stop forking the code paths once a feature is available everywhere, in a sustainable and informed way.

talks.title: 10 things you didn't know you can do with a linter
talks.speaker: Senja Jarva
talks.description: Linters (e.g. eslint, stylelint) are common tools in FE development. Usually linters are configured to point out possible error situations related to JavaScript's curiosities (e.g. strict equality vs loose equality with eqeqeq rule), to follow a certain code style (remember the Airbnb config?) or follow a recommended ruleset from a library eslint plugin (e.g. eslint-plugin-react). But, have you seen a linter used to teach how to use a certain library? Or to manage tech debt (or at least make sure the debt does not spread)? How about make sure that the agreed conventions are being followed? In this talk, I will go through the basics of the linter and plugin ecosystem(s), list how we are using linters currently and demonstrate how we could unleash the full potential of using linters to speed up and make FE development easier.

talks.title: The Internet in Real-Time: Demystifying WebSockets and WebRTC
talks.speaker: Sebastian Aarnio
talks.description: Real-time communication on the web opens up interactive possibilities beyond just conference calls. In this talk, we'll explore the power of WebSockets and WebRTC, how they work, when to use each, and how they can make your applications responsive and more engaging. You’ll learn how WebRTC's peer-to-peer connections support more than video, along with tips and security considerations. Through a live demo, we'll implement a web app that combines WebRTC and WebSockets, giving an example of combining the two browser-native technologies.

talks.title: You might not need a framework
talks.speaker: Matias Huhta
talks.description: In this live-coding demonstration we'll go through some of the modern API's you can utilize in all evergreen browsers. We'll discuss the pro's and cons of having a lower dependency count in your project and some recipes on making a no-build setup for your next web application. The talk will include implementing most of the features most commonly utilized in popular frameworks / libraries like React and Vue.

talks.title: Get Lost, JavaScript: Just Kidding — But HTML & CSS Do More Now
talks.speaker: Daniel Yuschick
talks.description: If your head has spun in the last few years trying to keep up with the latest evolutions of HTML and CSS, you’re not alone. Join us as we explore how these foundational technologies are shedding their static stereotypes and embracing dynamic interactivity, blurring the lines traditionally drawn by JavaScript. In this talk, we'll dive into the latest HTML and CSS features that are reshaping UI development. Learn how these features are gradually reducing our reliance on JavaScript in the 'front' of the frontend and moving some accessibility concerns, dynamic positioning, robust animations and more to the browser. Get lost, JavaScript! Just kidding. We still need you, but HTML and CSS do a lot more now.

talks.title: pg_render: Rendering HTML in SQL
talks.speaker: Matias Kaskimies
talks.description: What if you skipped backend and frontend and instead rendered your application in the database? Meet pg_render, a PostgreSQL extension written in Rust and PLpgSQL that generates HTML frontend directly in SQL functions. In this talk, we’ll explore the motivation, design and philosophy of this experimental approach. Through a live demo, we’ll discuss the idea of looking at software development from a data-schema-driven viewpoint, and its implications for traditional frontend-backend workflows. Perfect for anyone curious about pushing the boundaries of databases, software paradigms and crazy ideas.

talks.title: Who needs Web 3 when we can have Web 1.9
talks.speaker: Mikko Harju
talks.description: We’ll learn ourselves some HTMX, a technology that makes it possible to bring the best parts of handling rendering on the server side but still enabling interactivity beyond full page reloads.

talks.title: SolidJS vs React.js - Same same, but different
talks.speaker: Kurre Ståhlberg
talks.description: During the day I build Gubbe with React.js, at night I build phisherie.com with SolidJS. In this talk I discuss their similarities and differences, as they are very similar in many ways, but have some fundamental differences that have tripped me up many times so far.

talks.title: Leveraging CSS variables beyond --color-blue
talks.speaker: Teemu Suoranta
talks.description: Many developers are familiar with CSS variables but use them in very limited way. CSS variables are not just replacement of the variable system found in SCSS but a whole new approach. I will show you how to get most out of CSS variables for real world projects.

talks.title: Implementing TC39 proposal Map.prototype.upsert for SpiderMonkey and V8
talks.speaker: Mikhail Barash
talks.description: JavaScript is an actively evolving language, and its design is overseen by the Technical Committee TC39 of Ecma International. I'll explain briefly how TC39 works and give a concrete outline of the steps needed to implement a new language feature. The talk is based on our own experience [ https://bldl.github.io/upsert-tutorial/ ] in implementing the Map.prototype.upsert proposal for the Firefox SpiderMonkey and Google V8 engines. I will also explain how to read the ECMA-262 specification, which is a skill necessary for any JavaScript developer who really wants to understand how a certain language feature is supposed to work. The talk is suitable for everyone interested in JavaScript, and especially for those who want to know how to suggest a new language feature and participate in implementing it. Mikhail is a delegate at Ecma International TC39, the standardizing body behind JavaScript. He is a co-chair of the TC39-TG5 Task Group on Experiments in Programming Language Standardization, and a member of Ecma International's Executive Committee. He works at the University of Bergen (Norway), where he leads the language tooling team of Bergen Language Design Laboratory.

special.name: Afterwork at John Scott's
special.description: A chill after work at the local pub.

talks.title: A front(end) dive into the European Accessibility Act
talks.speaker: Eyal Eshet
talks.description: The European Accessibility Act (EAA) will be enforceable starting 28.6.2025. It expands accessibility requirements to consumer products and services, including e-commerce, banking, and transportation. Developers have a key role in ensuring services conform with the EAA. Join us for a front-end exploration of the EAA, the products and services it covers, conformance requirements, enforcement, and how you can help.

talks.title: Lightning talk extravaganza
talks.speaker: Dan Palmer, Lauri Huhta, Aarni Koskela, Mikko Harju and Konsta Purtsi
talks.description: Dan Palmer, Lauri Huhta, Aarni Koskela, Mikko Harju and Konsta Purtsi improvised 5-minute lightning talks based on topics suggested by the audience.
